connector.description: Send and receive messages to/from Google Cloud Platform PubSub Service.

camel.sink.endpoint.ackMode.name: camel.sink.endpoint.ackMode
camel.sink.endpoint.ackMode.description: AUTO = exchange gets ack'ed/nack'ed on completion. NONE = downstream process has to ack/nack explicitly One of: [AUTO] [NONE]

camel.sink.endpoint.concurrentConsumers.name: camel.sink.endpoint.concurrentConsumers
camel.sink.endpoint.concurrentConsumers.description: The number of parallel streams consuming from the subscription

camel.sink.endpoint.loggerId.name: camel.sink.endpoint.loggerId
camel.sink.endpoint.loggerId.description: Logger ID to use when a match to the parent route required

camel.sink.endpoint.maxMessagesPerPoll.name: camel.sink.endpoint.maxMessagesPerPoll
camel.sink.endpoint.maxMessagesPerPoll.description: The max number of messages to receive from the server in a single API call

camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.name: camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer
camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.sink.endpoint.serializer.name: camel.sink.endpoint.serializer
camel.sink.endpoint.serializer.description: A custom GooglePubsubSerializer to use for serializing message payloads in the producer

camel.sink.endpoint.synchronous.name: camel.sink.endpoint.synchronous
camel.sink.endpoint.synchronous.description: Sets whether synchronous processing should be strictly used, or Camel is allowed to use asynchronous processing (if supported).

camel.component.google-pubsub.endpoint.name: camel.component.google-pubsub.endpoint
camel.component.google-pubsub.endpoint.description: Endpoint to use with local Pub/Sub emulator.

camel.component.google-pubsub.lazyStartP.name: camel.component.google-pubsub.lazyStartProducer
camel.component.google-pubsub.lazyStartP.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.component.google-pubsub.publisherC.name: camel.component.google-pubsub.publisherCacheSize
camel.component.google-pubsub.publisherC.description: Maximum number of producers to cache. This could be increased if you have producers for lots of different topics.

camel.component.google-pubsub.publisherC.name: camel.component.google-pubsub.publisherCacheTimeout
camel.component.google-pubsub.publisherC.description: How many milliseconds should each producer stay alive in the cache.

camel.component.google-pubsub.autowiredE.name: camel.component.google-pubsub.autowiredEnabled
camel.component.google-pubsub.autowiredE.description: Whether autowiring is enabled. This is used for automatic autowiring options (the option must be marked as autowired) by looking up in the registry to find if there is a single instance of matching type, which then gets configured on the component. This can be used for automatic configuring JDBC data sources, JMS connection factories, AWS Clients, etc.

camel.component.google-pubsub.publisherT.name: camel.component.google-pubsub.publisherTerminationTimeout
camel.component.google-pubsub.publisherT.description: How many milliseconds should a producer be allowed to terminate.
